result.heading: FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT -1- THE STUNTMAN FADE IN

direction.raw_text: .   ROADSIDE DINER - EARLY MORNING A strip of two-lane highway runs through a tall pine forest. There is a truck-stop coffee shop beside the roadway. A few 14-WHEELERS are scattered across the big dusty parking lot. Morning sunlight glints off their chrome stacks. It bakes the asphalt and warms the mangy hides of stray DOGS asleep in the dirt. A HELICOPTER hovers about the treetops like a lazy hummingbird. It's the beginning of a perfect day. A highway PATROL CAR slowly trolls among the trucks and dogs and parks beside the slat and shingled building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: are scaling a power pole at the forest's edge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - ANGLE ON TELEPHONE LINEMEN High on the pole, the linemen lean back against their safety straps to work, their bodies forming a "Y." One of them suddenly turns, pointing at a nearby treetop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grabs a PORCELAIN INSULATOR from his belt, cocks his arm and hurls it across the open stretch. It lands smack in the middle of the tree. SQUAWK! A rattle of leaves, a rustle of feathers and a
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Lookee there!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: comes flapping out. The lineman cackles over his marksmanship.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - MOVING SHOT The big, frightened beady-eyed bird is lumbering through the sky, flapping for its life and suddenly...SPLAT! It crashes head-on into
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the bubble of the passing HELICOPTER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   HELICOPTER The ship rocks as the PILOT wrestles the controls. There are THREE OTHERS in the cabin. The man beside the pilot, ELI CROSS, is sketching in a manuscript and eating an apple. He glances up in irritation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli bites into his apple, grimacing at the mushy mouthful    He tosses it out the hatch.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, will you stop wiggling?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't yell at me...yell at the goddamn crazy bird! It tried to kill us!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (back to his manuscript) Oh yeah, that's your story. What's the bird got to say about it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   FOREST - TREETOPS The apple drops into the trees, bounces down from branch to branch and falls on the slanted roof of the ROADSIDE DINER beneath. It rolls down the eaves, off the edge and lands on top of the parked Highway Patrol car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   PATROL CAR FIRST POLICEMAN Something hit the roof.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They climb out as we see a SECOND PATROL CAR sliding up behind them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So will the Chief...if we don't grab this guy Cameron.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: emerge from the second car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   DINER - ON POLICEMEN They huddle, then move toward the diner entrance.     As they pass an open WINDOW the CAMERA HOLDS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: serves behind the long counter where MEN on stools eat watching the overhead TV. There is a PINBALL MACHINE in action. The policemen are seen ENTERING b.g. A TRUCK DRIVER ambles up and straddles a stool.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The fry cook fills the driver's empty water glass from a pitcher, then move down the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sits a few stools away. He's about 25, even-featured, bone- weary. His appealing face needs a shave. The cook fills his water glass. The ice cubes rattle as Cameron's hand trembles. His eyes are riveted on the policemen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Gettin' hot early. It's gonna be a scorcher.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Two policemen take seats at a booth across from the counter; one policeman moves to a WALL TELEPHONE, another stands near the CASH REGISTER looking at a magazine. They seem nonchalant, but are placed to block all avenues of escape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly startled as someone slaps him on the arm.       He whirls to face the man beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The MAN is staring at the TATOO which shows below the rolled-up sleeve of Cameron's shirt, a large American Eagle with elaborate scrollwork and a patriotic slogan. The man pulls up his own sleeve to show a small tatoo of an anchor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cameron rises and moves across the diner to the pinball machine.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's really a beaut...really a beaut!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My wife still yells about this...but yours -- that's some eagle...like a billboard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (eyes on police) Yeah, that's the grand old bird. (a half-smile) Right now I just wish the son-of-a- bitch could fly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The PLAYER wiggles and contorts, using body English to influence the balls.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey Morton, you think your ass is connected to the machine? You wiggle, it's gonna make the ball go where you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Cameron's eyes scan the room, passing the TV above the counter. On it, the commercial shows a beautiful girl (who we'll later know as
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ) bending over a bowl of dog food. Her ass, too,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: wiggles engagingly. The pinball player leaves the machine. Cameron, stalling for time, works the plunger while a cop stalks closer; like the cat to the mouse hole.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cameron shoots. The ball bounces crazily inside the machine, lights and buzzers flashing. Another policeman approaches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rests his hands on the machine, glancing about.    Escape seems hopeless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In a lightning-swift motion, the cop clamps his hands down over Cameron's wrists, snapping the HANDCUFFS on. The trap has sprung.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, you're lucky. Somebody left a free ball.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh huh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got 20,000! You're gonna win...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Win what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A free game!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Terrific...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...that's just what I needed...one more chance to lose.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Cameron nods his head in resignation. A big uncontrollable grin breaks and spreads over the cop's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then suddenly, Cameron bolts, desperately springing full speed for the back door. He flings it open. The cops are moving toward him. One has almost got his gun out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cameron lunges through the doorway, not realizing in his frenzy the screen door still blocks his path. He tears through it, but gets stuck halfway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Swinging his manacled arms like a club against the tangled mesh, he breaks free and runs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Cameron!   Halt! I'll shoot!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (panicked) No!...God, don't shoot!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   REAR OF DINER As Cameron flies down the back steps, a COP stationed at the rear door, caught off-guard, tries to stop him but is shoved flat on his back. Cameron weaves and scrambles across the yard, over fences, between the shed and the barn, rolling beneath a building, out the other side. Behind him, distant shouts and a gunshot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   FOREST - MOVING SHOT ON CAMERON - DAY As Cameron runs, he moves with a skill that suggests forests are not alien to him. He crouches low, following tiny avenues in the maze of tree trunks, scrambling on all fours over needles and fallen cones. Sweat pours down his face. His breath rasps in his throat. He breaks into a clearing and FREEZES...suddenly face to face with a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: who crouches, blocking his path. It is one of the telephone linemen we saw earlier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE The lineman, kneeling at his tool chest, is surprised by Cameron. The other lineman is halfway up the power pole. They both stare at Cameron's handcuffs. Cameron edges back, his escape route blocked. The man on the ground grabs a WRENCH and moves forward with the same gleam in his eye we saw when he scared that bird from the tree.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The lineman advances on him as Cameron backs away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The lineman jumps in surprise. Then, enraged like a startled bull, he lunges forward with the wrench. Cameron uses the man's weight against him, his moves those of a trained fighter. A hard knee to his stomach doubles up the lineman. The handcuffed arms slam down like a club between his shoulder blades driving him to the ground. A kick thrown sideways to his head and the man is out. The other lineman who had started to descend the pole freezes and takes one step back up. Cameron grabs the lineman's toolbox in his handcuffed grasp and dashes off into the forest.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Stand right there like a good old boy and do what I say. You wanna try and mess with me, you've had fair warning. I was a combat Marine in Korea. Okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Korea? No shit, so was my old man... (he suddenly stamps his foot and shrieks) Aaaaaaaargh!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He slides down a slope on a carpet of fallen leaves, tumbling to the bottom and falls face forward into a running stream where he holds his head and drinks. CAMERA MOVES ACROSS the terrain. There are no pursuers, the forest is silent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: UP - HANDCUFFS The jaws of a wire-cutter clamp down severing the chain connecting the cuffs around Cameron's wrists. He lifts his knee from the cutter handle. His arms are now free. He wedges a chisel against one bracelet and swings a sledgehammer against it. We hear his sharp outcry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doubled up, holding his wrist in pain. The bracelet is still intact. He buttons his shirt cuffs over the metal bands and climbs the slope to the bright sunlight on the road above.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   OLD ABANDONED ROAD - DAY Cameron is trudging along the old road winding down through the mountainous pass. He crosses a bridge. Through the arches of its low stone railing, he sees a BLACK RIVER twenty feet below rushing toward the sea. Then, glancing back, he is suddenly alert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the far distance, almost lost in the shimmering heat waves from the road, is a tiny speck moving toward him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He clambers down the embankment behind the railing, peering out from this hidden vantage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The speck grows larger. The SOUND of the engine is faintly audible now. Sunlight flashes from metal and glass. Cameron's apprehension suddenly changes to wonderment, for the vehicle is not the police as he had feared, but something else. Moving in the shimmering heat wave is a splendid, high, humpbacked World War I vintage DUESENBERG SEDAN with gleaming brass headlights, roaring towards him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He scrambles up the embankment to thumb a ride. The Duesenberg roars past him, filling his eyes and mouth with dust. Suddenly there is a screech of brakes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Duesenberg goes into a skid and then bounces to a stop. Running, Cameron reaches the car, pulls the front door open and climbs in beside the DRIVER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   CAR CAMERON Thanks.    I thought you didn't see me. The driver, BURT, is a husky, red-haired man about Cameron's age and deeply agitated. Pounding his fist against the steering wheel, he talks half to Cameron, half to himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fishing a Vick's inhaler from his pocket and shoving it in his nostril.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cameron looks at him, puzzled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Burt whirls on him, enraged.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He puts his boot in Cameron's stomach and shoves hard.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Damn it.    Screwed it up.   Lost my nerve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goddamn sinuses. Can't even see straight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want me to drive?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell is that supposed to mean?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (confused) No offense...thought you might...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Every one of you jerks is a goddamn hotshot expert! Thanks for the vote of confidence. If you think you can do any better, just come and try it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   CAR Cameron comes flying out and lands on his back in the road as the Duesenberg squeals forward, its open door slamming shut from the momentum. Stunned, the wind knocked out of him, Cameron rises to his elbows. Before the old relic has gone thirty yards, again the brakes screech, swinging the car into a sliding salute turn, one hundred- eighty degrees and it is suddenly screaming back toward Cameron.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   CAR - ANGLE ON BURT Driving with one hand on the door handle, his head halfway out the window watching the bridge railing and the water beyond.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cameron, sprawled on the road, is momentarily paralyzed at the sight of the Duesenberg's great brass grill bearing down. His hand closes over a rock and with the same illogical gesture that a soldier flings a Coke bottle at a tank, Cameron hurls the rock in the direction of the car and frantically rolls sideways. The big spinning tires brush him as they pass. We catch a momentary glimpse of the rock smashing against the gleam of the passing windshield. As he stops rolling, once more face down in the dust, eyes closed, expecting death, he becomes aware there is only silence. He opens his eyes, climbs to his feet. The road is empty. The Duesenberg is gone. Astonished, confused -- he walks to the side of the bridge where the railing ends and the car might have plunged off. There is nothing below but the rushing black water. Here and there bubbles swirl to the surface. They could be from a sinking car or could be caused by the current.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: - CAR AND CAMERON
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: His thoughts racing. Was it the sun, has he imagined the whole thing? Suddenly a HELICOPTER appears, hovering, almost at eye level. Sunlight flashes through the spinning blades like a strobe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE It is the same helicopter we saw in the opening sequence. It has swiftly descended beside the bridge just beyond the railing, catching Cameron with no chance to run or hide. FOUR MEN Can be seen inside the plastic cockpit barely a few feet away. The man beside the PILOT is ELI CROSS. He grabs the radio microphone and begins speaking into it. Cameron whirls, scrambles down a bank to a field. The helicopter drops to within a few feet of the water, hovers. Protected from sight, Cameron runs between the tall stalks, away from the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - MOVING SHOT Glancing back through the stalks as he runs, Cameron sees a STAKE TRUCK barreling toward the sight of the accident. In the back,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: are frantically putting on black wet-suits. They look, from this distance, like little black toys tumbling against each other. Cameron runs on. - 10 -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   BLUFF - OVERLOOKING SEASHORE TOWN A few hotels, like a cluster of old Victorian gingerbread, surround a sandy cove beyond which is the sea. There is a fishing pier, boardwalk, hot dog stands, pizza parlors, all swarming with sunbathing TOURISTS. The town's bucolic, turn-of-the-century charm might even survive these, if not for a monstrous yellow CONSTRUCTION CRANE, which juts ten stories into the sky from the center of the sandy cove. Cameron appears on the bluff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Surveying the town -- expressionless, a jungle beast going to survive no matter what -- at least for a few more hours. He reaches down and rips off his trouser legs at the thigh, turning them into cutoffs a vacationing bather might wear. He pulls off his worn boots and flings them into the brush, his eyes never leaving the town below. There are crowds to get lost in down there. He unbuttons his sleeve and looks at the handcuff still encircling his wrist. Stopping beside a large rock, he smashes the bracelet against it. It won't open. Grimacing in pain, he re-buttons the sleeve, opens his shirt and begins descending the palisades toward the town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   BOARDWALK The SCREEN is yellow and on it are the words: 'HAVE A NICE DAY.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: WIDENS and we realize the words are on the back of a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: that jiggles as its wearer walks. It is Cameron. Beyond him we see the tide of tourists in oils and ointments flirting with the sun. Teenage girls at portable toilets adjusting their bikinis. The boardwalk cops in white shirts, looking like ice cream vendors, whom Cameron deftly avoids. Then, he looks up at the sky, perplexed: the helicopter from the bridge is overhead, circling. Cameron watches it warily as he walks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: has formed at the railing of the pier. Many of the people with CAMERAS CLICKING at the sand below. Cameron notices the helicopter is now sharing the sky with a brightly painted open cockpit BIPLANE. It is a WORLD WAR I FIGHTER with BRITISH INSIGNIA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cameron works his way through the crowd. All eyes now look upward at the plane. A LOUD VOICE is HEARD coming through an electric
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cameron's world has become more ordered again. It's a film company shooting on location -- this somehow must explain the Duesenberg. His eyes go to the scene below.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: All right, people. Quiet! We're losing the sun! This is a take! You're welcome to watch, but please, no flashbulbs. They'll spoil the shot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: suspended from the end of the yellow construction crane is PHOTOGRAPHING the surf where EXTRAS in German WWI uniforms unload ashore. The bright little plane has started a lazy dive toward the soldiers, its engine whining. From here it looks as fearsome as Snoopy and the Red Baron.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the British plane pulls out of the dive, there is a tremendous explosion. In the flash of smoke and flame, barge, rowboats, ammunition and people are blown sky-high. The smoke from the exploding ammunition momentarily obscures the scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The onlookers are very impressed and pleased and then abruptly their pleasure turns to horror and disbelief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the smoke lifts, the Tom and Jerry violence has become a horrifying reality. Bodies are scattered about. One man has been severed in half, drenched in blood. Chunks of meat, arms and legs litter the beach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paralyzed by the sense of catastrophe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then, people begin to moan and scream. - 12 -
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (shouting) Something went wrong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Staring tensely at the carnage.      By reflex, a shout escapes his lips.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Medic!   Get the medics!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: sags into a faint.      A small child in the crowd is crying and clutching Cameron's leg.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the scene continues we hear a voice on the Bullhorn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly the reality of the horror turns into an obscene, absurd farce as what appear to be the missing parts of bodies begin wriggling out of the sand where the extras were partially buried to create the macabre effect and now the extras become whole human beings before our eyes once again.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Cut!   I said CUT! That's a print.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The crowd reacts in various ways. Sighs of relief, laughter, anger. The exhumed extras wipe sand from their eyes and shake it down their trouser legs. A.D. (yelling) Beautiful, Harvey. You gave everybody a heart attack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the Second Unit Director, yells back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The crowd disperses.      A TOURIST turns to Cameron.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The tourist stiffens as Cameron turns away, his attention now drawn by the beating sound of the helicopter. He glances up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Eli will hate it. He said he wanted the shot in one? Now watch, he'll do six hours of pick-ups.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Great...but why do they always use so much blood? It ruins the realism, don't you think? - 13 -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (still shaken, quietly mutters) ...asshole...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The helicopter is descending toward the beach while the FILM CREW rapidly moves equipment from the last scene into piles to clear a landing site.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wary of the men in the chopper, Cameron is moving down the pier away from the landing site. Suddenly he stops short, caught by something he sees O.S. Excitedly he points and begins to shout.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey!    Hey you...!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Below him, walking away on the sand is one of the actors with the same red hair, the same old British army jacket as Burt -- the man in the Duesenberg. Hearing the shout, the actor stops and tentatively turns. It's a mistake. Clearly the features are different. It's not Burt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cameron is puzzled. He watches as the red-haired actor looks about to see who called and finding no one, starts off, but is stopped by a LITTLE OLD LADY holding a parasol and offering her autograph book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Raymond signs the book with the easy charm of a man who's done it a million times. He has those special rugged good looks that belong to Marlboro men and movie stars. - 14 -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sound of the chopper blades has become deafening as it hovers for a landing. The Old Lady snatches her autograph book and heads for the landing site.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Bailey! Aren't you Raymond Bailey, the actor? Would you please sign your autograph? Write 'to Emily...for eternal peace.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm certainly glad you're all right. I lost my husband and my son in the wars...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As it touches the ground and its doors fly open. Out step the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and ELI CROSS. The ASSISTANT DIRECTOR rushes up and shouts over the hissing blades of the idling chopper. A.D. What happened on the bridge?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their words are lost in the sound of the rotor as the chopper slowly rises. The sudden WIND from its blades blows some screening off a pile of equipment. It falls on the Little Old Lady who has been approaching Eli and topples her into the surf. She is trapped in a tangle of ancient skirts and petticoats. Before she can regain her balance, a wave tumbles her further into the sea.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (deeply upset) All the divers found in the car was the goddamn camera. A.D. (stunned) And Burt?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (anguished) No Burt! All gone...caught in the current probably and...they're diving downstream and searching the riverbanks, but...don't say anything to the crew yet... A.D. (softly) Jesus Christ.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, Jesus Christ. A.D. What do you want to do? - 15 -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know...call my mother and have her tell me it wasn't my fault... (desperately) ...What the hell could have happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: INCLUDING CAMERON Cameron, sitting on the edge of the pier over the water, has watched this mini-disaster. The undertow from the wave has swept the Old Lady directly beneath him. Reaching down toward her, he yells:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He can't quite reach her. As a last resort, he drops off the edge into the water by her side.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey!   Hey, give me your hand!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He grabs for the struggling Old Lady.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like groping through seaweed, he reaches past her tangled skirts, grasps her waist and lifts her to keep her head above water. She is choking, gasping for air. She turns her face toward him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be afraid! You're gonna be okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Her features are distorted; they seem to be melting away. She frees her hand and violently tears at her face, pulling away the RUBBER MASK on which is the melting putty and make up. With it goes her wig and what is left is a startlingly beautiful young girl. - 16 -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sun glistens on the wet, wild young perfection of her face, ingenuously sparkling laughter and for an instant it's breathtaking - a universal boyhood fantasy to suddenly be thrown this close to that kind of "movie star" beauty. It's something Cameron feels in the pit of his stomach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Regaining his composure enough to attempt flattery, but he means it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they are only in a few feet of water, there is no longer any reason to hold her. He starts to put her down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grinning, he carries her toward shore. - 17 -
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: My God! (choking on water) You're...I know you...that girl from
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...the actress. Nina...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sputtering) ...Franklin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My God!...Why the hell...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing and choking) ...Makeup test...it's for the film...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They gotta be crazy to cover that face.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing) I'm only old at the end of the story.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, don't do that.    Rescue me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In three feet of water?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh come on, please. I always wanted someone to rescue me from something...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Eli, surrounded by the crew and dozens of tourists, is standing at the water's edge as Cameron wades in and sets Nina down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the sight of Eli, she becomes like a little girl who, having skinned her knee and run to daddy, now can allow herself to cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nina is surrounded by people who are rubbing her with towels, taking pictures, all shouting at once. The CROWD closes in, excluding Cameron to the outskirts.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Nina! You damned near scared me to death!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh hell, it's all ruined now and I wanted you to see the makeup, Eli. Where were you?...I even got Raymond's autograph and he didn't know...You'd have been proud...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the A.D.) Get her into a tub, then bed...and I want to see her in makeup and costume again before dinner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: hustle her off, as she searches the crowd for Cameron...then spots him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cameron waves and starts to wander off as they whisk Nina away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey! Thank you! That was really gallant...rescuing an old lady!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He moves toward Cameron.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Eli trots up, Cameron tenses, finally facing this man who saw him from the helicopter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli begins to stroll along the sand toward the pilings which support the pier. Cameron hesitates, but Eli's manner compels him to follow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They have reached the pier.   Eli stops, he is watching something O.S.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns to follow Eli's gaze.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Wait a second!   I want to thank you, too!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't run away.   What is that, a habit with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I also smoke too much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You and Burt on the bridge...how about telling me what happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. He must've gone crazy. He tried to run me down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh?...Why would he do that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flustered) ...I didn't ask him why! All I know is he was comin' at me very fast. (quoting an axiom spouted by top sergeants in a thousand boot camps) 'You want to get home for Thanksgiving, you better figure the guy comin' at you is tryin' to kill you'...That's one thing I learned from the gooks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gooks?...That has a nostalgic ring...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You guys really used to call them gooks? I thought that was just Time Magazine. - 19 -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That was 'Nam. What should I call 'em, WOPS? Nobody'd known what I was talkin' about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: has driven onto the beach. From it, THREE OFFICERS have emerged. They are armed and efficient looking. The PRODUCTION MANAGER moves to greet them. Eli takes Cameron's wrist and gently pulls him back into the shadow of the pilings, (privately reacting to the handcuff he feels beneath the shirt). JAKE, the Chief, is irate enough to be clearly heard from this distance.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: All right, this time you've had it! Where is he?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Chief, I'm glad you dropped by. Eli says you gotta do something about all these people on the beach.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bellowing) Thirty minutes is what you've got to get your goddamn equipment off this beach and out of town!...You tell Eli Cross if your men are on the streets after four o'clock, I'll throw their ass in jail!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Eli squats down on his heels and leans back against a piling, smiling up at Cameron.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cameron studies Eli, not knowing what to make of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cameron half laughs despite himself.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Speaking of jail...would you get upset if I asked how many cops were after you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (suddenly grim) What are ya talkin' about? - 20 -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (off-hand) Your I.D. bracelet...the look on your face...the way you ran from the bridge... (with exaggerated delicacy) I...don't suppose you want to tell me what you did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No...I don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (brightly, with humor) ...Could I try categories?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (glancing O.S.) Ever done any stunt work?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How'd you like to be a stunt man? You look like you're in pretty good shape, fast on your feet. You could do it. (getting to his feet) Besides, You're not gonna have much choice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE Jake has spotted them and is approaching with his men and the Production Manager. Eli puts his hand on Cameron's shoulder and steps out into the sunlight.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (softly, to Cameron) Now, don't get hasty. And, remember your ass, it's just like mine... maybe I can save them both. - 21 -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (trailing after Jake) ...but we've gotta have three days to finish this picture...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (striding toward Eli) You said you'd be gone four days ago, before the season started. You lie, break promises... (he is now close enough and shouting at Eli) Cross, I've gone out of my way, but this time...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: beeps, clangs and passes between them, interrupting Jake and leaving him sputtering. As it departs, Eli seizes the moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is silence. Eli stands thoughtfully kicking the sand with his toe. Then Jake starts shouting again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli's words are exploding in Cameron's mind -- that illusory event on the bridge has crystallized into hard reality.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cameron vaguely understands that Eli is trying to pass him off as Burt and that he, somehow, may be saved by going along with this madness. Eli, turning to Jake, continues passionately...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Chief is dazed. If this is Burt, the stunt man, he is obviously alive. Jake goes to Cameron.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Chief stares at Cameron. His clothes and hair are wet. There is a small bruise on his cheek from when he fell out of the Duesenberg. He looks the part. Jake turns to Eli with resignation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks to the waiting police car, surrounded by TOURISTS snapping pictures. He glares at them, angry at the world. Eli puts his arm on Cameron's shoulder and leads him through the dispersing crowd toward the hotel. Eli is now easygoing and friendly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They have reached the steps of the HOTEL. A BUS has stopped in front. TOURISTS are piling out. The POLICE CAR pulls up and parks nearby. Jake and his men can be seen surveying the crowd. A.D. (shouting in b.g.) Eli! The crew's waiting.   We need the next setup!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be there in a minute! A.D. An Eli minute or a real minute?! Eli turns back to Cameron as they mount the steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The have reached the front door.   Eli holds it open for Cameron.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In exhaustion and resignation, Cameron nods and wearily closes his eyes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Jake, it's been a rotten morning. You're hot and tired. Let's go in, have us a drink and find out what's eating you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning beet red) Don't treat me like these other morons! You know goddamn well what's eating me is that Duesenberg on the bottom of the river with the dead man in it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean, that is a goddamn public bridge and a public river! You go there without permits, without any precautions and get a man killed!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gently) Jake...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No more bullshit explanations. Just go...before I figure out how to hang you with a manslaughter charge!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause; quietly) No explanations...don't have any. But, maybe he does... (staring at Cameron) Go ahead, ask him, Jake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wide-eyed) ...Now wait!...You're not blaming me for...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wheeling on Cameron) Why not, Burt?! Because you're a fake?! Because you're just a goddamn daredevil with a head full of marbles?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He grabs the bread, blows the shot, screws you up...screws me up. He's dumb, Jake, but thank God, he ain't dead yet. So do me a favor, put your handcuffs on this son-of-a- bitch and put him some place where he can't get hurt!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How did you get out of the car?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He didn't get out. Our divers got him out...and brought him back in the chopper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cross, when these three days are up, I'm going to arm my men with shotguns and tell them it's open season on any fruit carrying a camera.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You did that very well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't get a chance to say a word. I just listened.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There are only a few actors in the world who have mastered that art. Anyway, it was a good audition. You landed the part.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How? What about the crew? They going to look at me and say, 'Hi, Burt?'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Unless you prefer, 'Hi, Elizabeth.' Don't worry about my crew, they'll call you anything I want 'em to. Look, I'm not being callous. Burt is a fucking tragedy, but there's nothing in the world I can do about it...I've gotta have this location for three more days...and you need a place to hide.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The hand! Close-up of the hand!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: By tomorrow the local cops'll know what I look like. I can't hang around.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (expansively) "Burt," stop worrying! Haven't you heard of "movie magic?" (pointing to the etched glass doors of the hotel) That door is "the looking glass," and inside...is Wonderland. You're gonna pose as a stunt man, who's posing as an actor, who's posing as a character in a movie...who's posing as an enemy soldier...In that big a crowd, who's gonna notice you? People like to believe in things and cops are just people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with mock confidentiality) Frankly, your problem's so simple, it's almost beneath me. Have faith, 'Alice.' Close your eyes and enjoy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Open your eyes...and don't touch. It's wet. - 25 -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   HOTEL BASEMENT - CLOSE ON CAMERON'S REFLECTION His eyes open. He stares at his face in the mirror, pleased at the subtle transformation. His hair has been cut shorter and dyed red, somehow changing his whole aspect. He rubs the red mark on his wrists where the bracelet has been removed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Part of the laundry room is being used for the film's Hairdressing Department. Cameron sits in a barber chair wearing a plastic apron, surrounded by dryers, wigs, etc. In b.g., washing machines churn constantly. DENISE, the Hairdresser, an attractive earthy woman of thirty-two, stands over him. He is still wary and trying not to show it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She touches his hair to test the dryness, holding her hand there for a moment longer than seems necessary. He grins at her, rises and crosses to the wall mirror to get a better look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She moves to a basement window and gazes out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (looking in mirror) ...Could be worse...could be green...I think I like it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course you like it...ask anybody... Denise gives great hair. Got any grass?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking his head) Nope.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What else don't you have that I need?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Through the window, the crew is setting up a shot while Eli rehearses with Nina and his red-haired male star, RAYMOND BAILEY, (who Cameron earlier saw on the beach). Bailey is dressed as a World War I British aviator and Nina as a young girl of that era.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Our male star isn't going to like you... - 26 -
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (moving toward window) Why not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He studies the view, his attention focused on Nina.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Moving to a pile of laundry heaped on the floor, she pokes around with the toe of her shoe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Snaring a crumpled garment, she kicks it toward Cameron, who catches it instinctively, then holds it up for inspection -- a pair of (Nina's) lace panties. He grins, mildly embarrassed by the charade. - 27 -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She reaches for the panties, but instead takes his hand and yanks sharply, pulling him off balance, falling back on the laundry pile with Cameron on top of her, their faces inches apart; surprise on his, amusement on hers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cameron is trying to remember: what was it Eli said? "Close your eyes, relax and enjoy." Across the room the washing machines churn, whirl and heave.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You're too good looking. His idea of a perfect stunt double is two- hundreds pounds of hamburger in a red wig...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's she like? I've seen her on
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (irritated by his interest in Nina) At selling douche powder, she's fabulous; dog food?...I'm not sure she's sincere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you sore about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not sore. Isn't that what you wanted to know? (with sarcasm) ...Or did you mean, what's the real Nina Franklin like--without the greasepaint and tinsel...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...You mean, what's she like -- underneath?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (moving toward him) What do those say about the girl who wears them? Shy? Delicate? Sensitive?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (touching his hair) Still wet...very wet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   BEACH AREA Eli and his crew are shooting a scene: a "pick-up" shot for the explosion sequence we saw earlier. Eli and GABE, the cameraman, are lying beside the camera. Before them, the "severed" arm protrudes from the sand in which its owner is buried, out of sight.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You sure he can breathe? (a mumbling assent from beneath the sand) Where's Raymond? (Raymond kneels beside him) Remember, you just crashed...you were wandering the beach behind the German lines looking for a place to hide when you saw the explosion. You're stunned by the carnage. That bomb was dropped by a guy in your squadron. Okay? Roll the film.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: THRU CAMERA Through the CAMERA, WE SEE the 'arm' protruding from the sand. We
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: o.s. VOICES yelling: "Turning"... "speed"... "action." We see the fingers begin to move spasmodically. Eli's voice yells: "Okay, Raymond!" Suddenly the fingers on the hand start to swell, bigger and bigger...like a rubber glove filling with air...then BANG! BANG!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! The (balloon-covered) fingers EXPLODE. - 28 -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone has broken up with laughter at the prank, including Eli. Gabe is patting Eli's face, Raymond squeezing his jaw affectionately as one would a pet dog's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli climbs to his feet as the laughter subsides. Cameron, now wearing a uniform exactly like Raymond's, watches from the sidelines.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is great sadness among them.     Eli breaks the mood lightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cameron crosses to them. He and Raymond stand appraising each other, red-haired men in identical uniforms. As Raymond offers his hand:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (cackling) Gotcha that time! Didn't we?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (through his laughter) Yeah, you got me another half-hour behind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gently, grinning) Thought the chief could use a little cheering up today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning quiet and serious) ...So you heard the news about Burt...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nodding) Any more word?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bitterly) Afraid not...there's no picture ever made that's worth it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking his head) I'll never understand why these guys do it -- take the chances. - 29 -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (thoughtfully) Don't know. Trying to beat the system, I guess...we all know that some day we're gonna die of nothing more important than wrinkles...and that makes us so scared and crazy, we'll do anything. Go off bridges...fight windmills...wars... anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what our film's about -- or didn't you know? (sees Cameron) Hey, Burt, come over here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Eli) My new cock and balls?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quickly) Not new...It's important not to let that get around as yet. So, for the time being, let's make like he's the same guy. (adding a touch of color) But no longer known as "Bad-assed Burt." Ever since his 'fortunate rescue,'...we call him "Lucky."
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   CHURCHYARD - ANGLE ON CHUCK - LATER THAT DAY CHUCK BARTON is a tall, rugged-looking man in his mid-thirties, the Stunt Gaffer on Eli's film. A MESSENGER trots up and presents a receipt book. Chuck sets down his stunt bag and signs it absently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the Messenger leaves, Chuck strolls over to where Cameron stands waiting, circles around him, sizing him up. Cameron is no longer wearing the uniform, but now is in jeans and a work shirt.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Your film from that camera in the Duesenberg's on the way to the lab. Put it on the plane with my own little hands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When do we get it back?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't know. Stamped it "rush."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I stamp "rush" on my mare's ass, she'll still take eleven months to foal. Call the lab and find out when! (quietly) I lost a man today. I wanna see that footage and find out why.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Done any stunt work?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not really.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not really?   You have or you haven't?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (good-naturedly) I got out of Vietnam in one piece. Let me tell you that wasn't a bad stunt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (skeptically) That's ancient history.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Seems like yesterday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pointing at church steeple) Could you jump from that tower to the that roof? - 31 -
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Gauging the fifteen-foot gap between the CHURCH STEEPLE and the roof of the nearby MUNICIPAL BUILDING. He unconsciously grimaces at the four-story drop between them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He throws Cameron some knee pads from his stunt bag and begins marking off two lines on the bare earth between the gravestones in the churchyard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cameron hops up to the starting line, finishing with the knee pads clumsily, surveys the distance of not more than seven feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Makes a casual jump, landing on the line and looking at Chuck for approval.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes a running start and leaps hard.    While he's still in mid- air, Chuck yells.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cameron has landed three beyond the mark and looks up at Chuck a bit shaken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chuck launches himself head-first. His hands touch the ground just beyond the second mark to break his fall, easing him into a shoulder roll, he somersaults to his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes a running start and does the same.   Not quite as well, but well enough. As he rolls to his feet:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chuck turns on him enraged, overreacting. - 33 -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cameron is surprised to see that Chuck is grinning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chuck starts to walk away, then stops and looks at Cameron.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (being glib) Once, to save my ass, I jumped out of a banana tree into an oxcart full of buffalo shit. Does that count?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll see.    Put these on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (puzzled by the pads) Where do they go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tapping his knee) Under the pants. (pointing to lines he has drawn) I want you to jump from here...to there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okie-dokie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very good. Except you're dead!! Your brains are scattered all over the goddamn pavement. You landed on the edge and fell backwards four stories. Where do we send the body? - 32 -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (returns to the starting line) Don't bury me yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're still dead! You fell over the other side of the building.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You wanna try it right, once? You should land in a tuck-and-roll.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Show me, sergeant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very fancy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My speciality is Hopscotch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And Burt's specialty was drowning. You know one goddamn daredevil on this picture was enough! What the hell was Eli thinking, giving me a smart-ass, cocky, amateur kid when I need a stunt man! It's a little different running across that roof when they're pumping tracer bullets over your head.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (eloquently pleading his case) I was running for twenty-six months with guys shooting at me...not over my head...at my head and I'm alive. I knew daredevils. I got nothing against them...it's just they're all dead. So ease off and give me a chance...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (genuinely) Hey, were you putting me on?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Me?   I wouldn't know how to do that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   ROOFTOP MUNICIPAL BUILDING - CLOSE ON CHUCK - MINUTES LATER CHUCK (pained) Can you imaging Eli doing a World War I picture without horses? Do you know the gags I could do with four runaway horses pulling a caisson? Cameron sailing into the SHOT. Chuck ducks slightly, catching Cameron on his back and flipping him into a somersault. Cameron lands on the sharply slanted slate roof of the municipal building. Chuck stands beside him straddling the peak. The church steeple can be seen in b.g. (and we now realize time has passed and we are no longer in the graveyard of the previous sequence, but atop the building). - 34 -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cameron goes running at Chuck and once again flies over his shoulder. Sprawling on the slippery slate, he looks up to see Chuck strolling down the hazardous incline like a mountain goat. Cameron scrambles to follow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They have reached the lower edge of the roof.    Cameron looks down at the drop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chuck has stopped and they peer down through a skylight to where the crew is setting up a shot in a room below.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...Next time hit me higher.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (climbing to his feet) What's Eli got against horses?    I love horses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't butter me up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as he walks) We'll draw a sight line for you to follow down the roof here, while you're rolling. Now there's nothing very difficult. But this is where you gotta think. Your mind can't be on snatch. It's gotta be on grabbing that gutter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Or my brains are all over the pavement again, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (walking away) You know a good falling horse makes more money in four minutes than a bank president does in a year?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Picture's not over. Maybe you'll still get your chance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sadly) Naw, all they care about is story.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: They move to another edge of the roof overlooking a NARROW CENTRAL COURTYARD. They gaze down at a WINDOW AWNING two stories below that juts from the side of the building-wing across the court.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Now here's where the scuffle ends. When the pipe breaks loose, you fall and hit that awning. Then Eli yells "cut" and old Raymond takes your place for the close-ups and the glory. That's where the German soldiers catch him and throw him in the nuthouse. They're shootin' that scene downstairs now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (staring at awning) That's supposed to hold me? Probably doesn't hold rain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not a real awning, it's a catcher.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   MUNICIPAL BUILDING ROOF - CLOSE ON CAMERON - DAY Cameron's face is beginning to sweat and the veins are bulging from the growing strain of some physical effort.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's no harder up here than it is on the ground...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: to reveal Cameron dangling from a section of rain gutter, four stories above the ground.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's the same gag...it's just a little scarier. And that's what you get paid for.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (alert) Yeah, how much?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're stealing candy with this gag. You get six hundred bucks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (almost falling)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus!...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Christ! Watch it, will ya? (helping Cameron onto roof) What did you think a stunt man is? He's a professional. If the camera jams, that's another six hundred and if Eli says "try it again," six hundred more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (exultantly) Yahooo! Six-fucking-hundred-bucks!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   MUNICIPAL BUILDING - ASYLUM SET In a large vacant hall on the ground floor of the municipal building, a movie set has been erected representing the ward room in a World War I military asylum. In it, Eli's crew is filming a sequence -- a dozen enraged INMATES in tatters, heads shaven, wild- eyed, advance toward Raymond, shrieking (as though in echo of Cameron's exultant yell).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE Raymond, dressed as a British Flyer, his face bloodied, crouches and retreats in terror, a man caught in a nightmare, as these mutilated derelicts suddenly swarm over him. One, like a mad dog, goes fro his throat, another wields his own artificial limb as a club. Raymond (in character) breaks free and screams.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For an instant, the inmates stop in stunned silence -- broken only by a distant shout overhead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The slavering madmen look up, then out at the camera, madmen no longer, simply bewildered actors.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...STOP!...Get away!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on the roof overhead) ...Six-fucking-hundred, gorgeous, beautiful dollars! I can't believe it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right. Hold it! Hold it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Eli stands amidst the camera crew photographing the scene.   He is waving for order.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Eli steps down from the DOLLY, a solemn, quiet man approaches him from among the onlookers. It is SAM BAUM (the writer).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The A.D. Calls "Five minutes" and the crew moves toward the coffee urn. Eli wanders toward the door, Sam pursuing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli rips the page with the "madhouse scene" from his screenplay as they stride out of the building.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...Save it, everybody. A.D. (storming in) Jesus Christ, what the hell was that? Somebody get their ass up on that roof...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cutting him off) ...Never mind. I didn't like it anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The scene's wrong. (yells to the A.D.) Call a break.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (fighting for his scene) Eli, it played like a dream.   My God, it was Marat-Sade.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (glumly) It played like shit! - 38 -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (desperate) Well, who was that on the phone in the middle of the night when you first read it, raving about the magical madhouse scene, the upstairs maid?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   MUNICIPAL BUILDING There, beside the rear entrance on a pile of construction sand, sits Eli, cross-legged, staring morosely at some kids who play nearby. He is absently folding a torn script page into a paper airplane. Behind him, at a respectful distance, stand the Production Manager, A.D., half a dozen assorted crew chiefs and Sam Baum, all looking concerned. Sam looks at the others, shrugs and approaches Eli, squatting beside him on the sand pile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: While Sam talks, Eli takes a fistful of sand and pours it in Sam's shoe. Suddenly noticing, Sam yanks his foot away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sam has finished replacing his shoe and Eli pours a fistful of sand into Sam's other shoe.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What do you wanna do, Eli?... They're all waiting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (irritated) Being childish isn't going to help your movie...You know, there's nothing wrong with the story. (removing his shoe and shaking the sand out) The real problem is since I wrote this thing two years ago, you've had Watergate, the energy crisis, Women's Lib, the economy is down the tubes...You want to talk about burning issues?...There's arsenic in the glue on the back of food stamps! That's why you don't like the "madhouse scene." Your goddamn war story has lost its relevance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be negative, Sam. We can start a new one in time for the preview.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cut it out, will ya?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   HOTEL DINING ROOM - THAT NIGHT Eli is at the head of a long table, CAMERA PULLING BACK TO REVEAL a dozen members of the company dining with him. Nina sits beside Eli listening with rapt attention to Sam's monologue, her dessert fork sensuously lingers at her lip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The truth in Eli's statement registers on Sam. Cameron sits farther down the table, watching Nina watch Eli...and wishing she were watching him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cameron is starting to bristle at Eli's needling, particularly with Nina watching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The deadly in Eli's voice was more than intended and there is suddenly an awkward silence at the table. Cameron eyes Eli with a wry smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone laughs. Jake, the Chief of Police, is seen in the background approaching the table. Cameron spots him and starts to rise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cameron, realizing the film might disclose his presence on the bridge, reacts with alarm, which increases as Eli says...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then, suddenly noticing something different about Cameron's appearance...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jake pulls a PHOTOGRAPH from a manila envelope and hands it to Cameron.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Two years ago you were all charged up to make a great big anti-war statement and they wouldn't let you. Now they let you, but you haven't got a war. What you've got is egg on your face because Vietnam's long gone and it's too late!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Our picture's not about fighting wars...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...It's about fighting windmills.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: War isn't the disease...It's only one of the symptoms.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hooked) What's the disease? - 40 -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the big question, Sam. Name the disease and you've licked the screenplay. (indicating Cameron) Ask him. 'Cause he knows what the film is about. Right Lucky? Tell 'em...How'd you like Vietnam?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How'd you like bubonic plague?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You drafted?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See, Sam? Here's another one who hates war...but he enlisted. (to Cameron) You fought in Vietnam for two years? ...I mean actually were out there killing people...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Hey, I didn't kill that many people...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be modest, Lucky. Everybody digs a little violence...What was that you said on the beach?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: About what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: About getting home for Thanksgiving?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tentatively) ...that you better figure the guy coming at you is trying to kill you...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. See, Sam?...That's what the disease is about...being scared shitless. Inventing enemies. Whistling in the dark. I wish you'd talk to the kid, Sam, I mean it. You know, really, you guys should room together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (getting the last word) Hey, Lucky, give me your cot by the window and I'll let you read a great madhouse sequence.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (surrendering) All right, Eli. I'll write you another scene. What difference does it make? The studio will cut it all out anyway and what you got left is a lot of swell battle scenes, which, when I was back there they said were "just terrific."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (simply) No, they won't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, what makes you different?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) Because they know if they cut my picture, I'll kill 'em.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean, bang? Kill 'em, just like that? - 42 -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (matter of fact) No. I'll kill 'em and eat 'em...I hate to waste anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughs) They call him "Eli the Terrible..."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sam, my picture is the only kid I've got! If the studio said your daughter, Jennifer, would look better with her fingers chopped off, what would you do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Being an insecure writer, I'd call my agent...and get another opinion.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...If you'll excuse me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (arriving) Don't go away, Burt.   I want you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (broad welcome) Jake! Long time, no see. You taken care of my problem with the beach?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not talking to you. (to Production Manager) I understand you got that film out of the Duesenberg...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cutting in) It's at the lab, Jake. - 43 -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm talking to this gentleman. (to Production Manager) We want to see it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell the Chief it's our pleasure. Soon as it gets back...but ask him why.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (choked up with its importance) You can tell your Mr. Cross this inquiry comes from a source so high it is not his to question... (now at a loss for proper words) ...it is his to do it, or else. Someone they're looking for may have been on that road when the car went off. (to Cameron) Burt, you see anybody?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, did you have red hair before?...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indicating Denise) She sprays it every day so I look like Raymond...I didn't see a soul.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the rescue) Tell the Chief that Burt was so busy being brilliant, he wouldn't have noticed Jesus Christ walking on the water.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: PHOTOGRAPH
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A wire photo, front and side views of Cameron, taken at his military induction. War ages a man...he looks younger and quite different in his GI Haircut.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Hey, Burt! You got it upside down. The eyes go on top.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Cameron hands the photo back to the Chief, who passes it around the table. Denise receives the photograph, studies it and glances up at Cameron, expressionless. He returns her gaze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli takes the photograph.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli looks at Cameron with grudging admiration.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They mince off (the fag act all the more amusing because of Raymond's strictly masculine looks). Eli shouts after them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Raymond "gathers" Nina along the way, wrapping his arm about her shoulders -- Cameron watching silently. Then, charging from across the dining room like a tanker steaming in their wake, comes a gushing, overwrought, blue-rinsed MATRON.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) A couple of telephone linemen say they saw him headed this way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Looks like a nice clean-cut kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know about fifty guys who don't think so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What'd he do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Production Manager, ignoring Eli's question) The minute that film gets here you give me a call.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (yawning and rising) I don't know about those fifty guys, but I know one weary guy who's gonna crawl upstairs and hit the sack.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know a weary guy who's driving to Cape Long to dance and booze all night...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (camping, takes Gabe's hand) I know a weary gay who's going with him!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So long as you're back in ninety minutes. It's a work night for some of us. (loftily) ...Those who give a shit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Miss Franklin! Miss Franklin! Your 'Feminique Spray' commercial is on
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . My God, it's simply heavenly!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   CAMERON'S HOTEL ROOM - CLOSE ON DRESSER - NIGHT Drawers are slamming open and shut as Cameron hurriedly stuffs his few belongings into his pockets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE It's a mean little bedroom, with Sam's clothes, typewriter, etc., in evidence. Seeing Sam's wallet, Cameron pulls a wad of money from it, at the same time accidentally knocking Sam's false teeth off the dresser. He hesitates, then stuffs back all the bills but a twenty. He strides to Sam's closet, pulls out shirt and slacks, stuffs them in a cloth beach bag, also belonging to Sam and starts out the door. Then he stops, gets on his hands and knees, looking for the false teeth, which he finally finds. Now, annoyed at himself for being a "nice guy," he throws them carelessly on the dresser and quickly exits. - 46 -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .   HOTEL - LATER THAT NIGHT As Cameron moves down the steps, the returning company STATION WAGON pulls to a stop in the driveway. Nina, Raymond and a few others emerge from the car. Cameron turns away so as not to be seen as they pass him on the steps heading for the entrance.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Bet they're looking for that nut who killed all those campers in Montana...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (drunk) ...Too many campers, weed 'em out! ...Imagine, sitting an hour at a roadblock.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We should have waited, it wouldn't have been an hour.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: They've entered the hotel. Cameron continues to the bottom of the stairs, hesitates, looking back at Nina.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silhouetted through the etched glass doors (on the other side of "The Looking Glass") he sees the lithe, gay, exquisitely beautiful figure of Nina -- light sparkling from the cut glass dances about her face -- a hauntingly romantic image.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He watches for a moment with hopeless longing. Finally, turning from her, he looks about at the dark water and deserted boardwalk. There come some of Eli's crew, laughing, joking, cutting a swatch through the stillness, pushing their heavy brutes toward some nearby spot to light a night shot. There's the CHURCH TOWER. He stares at it, wavering in his resolve to leave, wondering what would happen if...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She has come up behind him, unnoticed.    He turns, startled, and there she stands. - 47 -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For a moment they search each other's eyes -- for intentions.   Then she glances at the tower.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cameron's mind is racing over all the things he'd like to say so she would know him instantly. But his answer is simple and sounds sincere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She understands the slightly jealous rebuke for her blind faith in Eli. Her laughing answer hangs like a challenge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For a moment he weighs it: whether to "run" or stay. Then acts on his decision. Starting to laugh, he takes her hand and pulls her toward the tower. She holds back, struggling playfully. - 48 -
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What next? Do you rescue the maiden from the tower?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiles) Hi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. It does look pretty high. (with concern) Are you worried about tomorrow?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not much. I guess if there were any real danger, Eli wouldn't let me do it, would he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quickly, reassuring) No. I'm sure it's safe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (abruptly, with a boyish grin) Good. Then you jump.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing) Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, come on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (willing, but flustered) What, right now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait, I'm afraid of heights!   What if I freeze up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pulling her along) Don't worry, I'll give you a push. Isn't that what a pal's for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   BELL TOWER - NIGHT It is crowded with bells, a small walkway and railing surrounded them. The city lights are seen beyond. Below are the sheds where crewmen are preparing the next day's shooting. Just beyond is the overwhelming silhouette of the huge CRANE. Nina and Cameron reach the top of the stairs winded and laughing, as they rush to the railing and lean over. Nina gasps, clutching Cameron in genuine fright.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She whirls to go.   He stops her, taking her by the shoulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her concern for him has turned to anger, like a mother slapping her child for running in the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His arm still restrains her. She takes hold of it, then suddenly softens with a look of slight surprise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After a moment, he answers quietly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's true. She is trembling and so is he -- not from fear. He slowly draws her toward him, her mouth reaching up to his. And then they are devouring each other. Abruptly, they're illuminated by a fierce blast of white light. They separate and stare, blinking in shock and confusion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are pinned in the crossbeams of two more giant arcs. Quickly she yanks him down with her out of sight behind the railing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (gasps) Oh, my God! It's terrifying! You can't jump from this...you'll get killed! It's crazy!...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing) ...It's not that bad. It looks worse at night... Chuck says it's like robbing a candy store.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (getting angry) Now stop that! ...I'm going back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...What's wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's just dumb...to strut around trying to talk brave...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh...you are scared...aren't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (seriously) Not really.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.   You are...You're trembling.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So are you...and you're not even gonna jump.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Okay, hit two and three.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   CHURCHYARD - ELI AND CREW - NIGHT Eli is lounging in the bucket suspended from the crane.   Beside him Gabe adjusts one of the giant brutes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabe smiles, scurries off. Eli glances at the tower, grins, having toyed with them long enough, he yells. - 50 -
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (business as usual) I could kill this brute and fill with juniors. You'd get a halo around the tower.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (struggling to resist) Got no time...it's an establishing shot...two seconds on the screen. (giving in) ...You got six minutes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey! While you're up there, be useful. We're lighting. Stand up and look towards the sea so you're in profile!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE ON TOWER - NIGHT As Nina's arm raises into view with the middle finger extended.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) (hollering) Light this, Eli!!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .   CHURCHYARD - BENEATH THE TOWER - NIGHT The church door swings open. Nina and Cameron emerge, covering their embarrassment with bravado. Nina is prattling as though to a tour guide.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...And those bells are so interesting. Imagine four hundred years ago by boat from Amsterdam. Thank you for the tour. It was so informative. I'm going to write my father. He's so interested in God and things like that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli miraculously appears from above. He descends and rides around beside them in the bucket of the crane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Unable to elude Eli in his basket, Nina turns on him in mock frustration.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Privately, she gives Cameron's arm an affectionate squeeze, then disappears around the corner of the building. He is left holding the beach bag, pursued by the Peter Pan in the basket. It has now dropped to ground level so Eli is looking up at Cameron.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eli's basket now moves up a few feet so he's looking down at Cameron, riding beside him while he walks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pulls Cameron into the basket beside him so unexpectedly that Cameron drops Sam's bag. Eli picks it up and plops it into Cameron's lap. Suddenly Cameron finds himself soaring skyward at a stomach-churning rate -- while Eli rattles on...probing, disarming, quixotic...
direction.name: direction
